content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 3 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player in this repeated game, I would consider the long-term strategy that maximizes my payoff across all three rounds.

In each round, choosing R nets 45$ if my opponent chooses the same, but 0$ otherwise. On the other hand, choosing B yields 20$ regardless of the opponent's choice, and there is a chance to earn 40$ when my opponent picks R.

Given that the game has three rounds, it seems more advantageous to choose R in the first round, since it pays out higher if the opponent chooses B. If they pick R as well, we both get 45$. However, if they respond with B after I picked R, I would still be better off in the long run due to the payout difference and having one more chance to earn more points in the remaining rounds.

If I choose R in round one and my opponent picks B, I can switch my strategy for the next two rounds to pick B, ensuring a consistent 20$ in each of those rounds. This results in a total payoff of (45 + 20 + 20) = 85$.

If my opponent picks R in response to my initial R, I can adapt and choose B for the following two rounds, earning 60$ ((40 + 20 + 20)).

In contrast, if I start by picking B in each round, my maximum payoff would be 60$. Therefore, choosing R in the first round seems to offer a higher long-term payoff, given that the opponent is likely to adapt their strategy based on my initial choice.

However, it's important to remember that I am playing against an anonymous player who may also be employing a strategic approach. They might try to exploit any perceived pattern in my choices or make unpredictable decisions to maximize their own payoff. In a real-world scenario, it would be essential to maintain flexibility and adaptability throughout the game.

You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In the second round, I will choose B. This decision ensures a consistent 20$ payout for me while giving my opponent an opportunity to deviate from their initial strategy. If my opponent chose R in the first round as well, they might be less inclined to do so again and could choose B instead, resulting in lower payoffs for both players.

By choosing B in this round, I maintain a total of 65$ (45 + 20) across the two rounds while allowing my opponent to earn only 60$. This slight advantage in the overall payoff motivates me to continue with the B choice in the third and final round.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

In the third and final round, I will choose B again. My opponent picked R in both previous rounds, which led to my earning a lower payoff compared to if they had chosen B. By consistently choosing B for the remainder of the game, I can ensure that I earn at least 20$ more than if we had alternated choices throughout the three rounds.

In this scenario, my final total payoff would be (40 + 20) = 60$. Although my opponent initially earned a higher payoff in round two by exploiting my first R choice, their lower total payout of (45 + 0 + 0) = 45$ still falls short of the maximum possible outcome of 60$.

Ultimately, while it is essential to employ strategic thinking when playing repeated games such as this one, adaptability and flexibility are key factors in achieving a favorable outcome over multiple rounds.
